Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WDG-YF41-JCF0-82DB-00000-00Pressure mounts for antitrust action against Silicon Valley giants2019-06-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:53ZLexisNexisPressure mounts for antitrust action against Silicon Valley giants

Four decades of strong deregulatory winds have helped carry today's tech titans -- Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google parent Alphabet -- to a level of global dominance that the railroad, steel and oil barons of the 19th century could only dream of.

Apple and Amazon both reached market cap valuations of $1 trillion in the past year. Google generated $136.8 billion in revenue in 2018. And Facebook boasts 2.3 billion monthly active users, or more than a third of the Earth's population.

Each company has faced complaints that their sheer size and scale give them monopoly status. But their rapid and largely unsupervised growth has created privacy and other risks for consumers.

Now, those regulatory winds may be starting to blow in another direction. After decades of inactivity, Congress, the Trump administration and investors are finding common ground to take on these companies.

The Federal Trade Commission and the Department of Justice, which share responsibility for antitrust enforcement, have reportedly arrived at something of a divide-and-conquer approach, with the DOJ taking on Apple and Google and the FTC digging into Amazon and Facebook.

The House Judiciary Committee has announced its own investigation of tech companies and their potential monopoly power. On June 3, the committee launched what it billed as a "bipartisan investigation" into the digital marketplace and the businesses that control it. Chairman Jerrold Nadler, a New York Democrat, said at a hearing that the committee is investigating because "there is growing evidence that a handful of gatekeepers have come to capture control over key arteries of online commerce, content and communications."

"Big Tech plays a huge role in our economy and our world," said the panel's ranking Republican, Doug Collins of Georgia. "More and more questions have arisen about whether the market remains competitive."

With bipartisanship so rare in the current Congress, particularly efforts to take on a massive business sector, it begs the question: Why now?

The answer is a combination of rising public concern over privacy and influence, as well as attention from 2020 presidential candidates and tougher measures by the European Union.

"Antitrust at its best was always historically bipartisan," says Maurice Stucke, a former prosecutor in the Antitrust Division at Justice who now works in the private sector with the Konkurrenz Group, teaches law at the University of Tennessee and has authored several prior and upcoming books on competition policy in the digital age.

"It isn't like we just woke up," Stucke says of the current regulatory push. "It's the grinding away. You look at every measure of our economy ... how is it helping most Americans? And when you look at the economic measures, most of them are still pointing to a market power problem. And so I think that you're getting this backlash."

Echoes From Long Ago

More than a century after the immense chasm of wealth inequality in the Gilded Age led to the first U.S. antitrust law, vast disparities in wealth and opportunity are similarly challenging today's social order. Piles of research from the past decade seek to compare that earlier era with the current one, with our tiny fraction of American multi-billionaires, a larger percentage of multi-millionaires and 40 million people living below the poverty threshold.

While economists study and argue about what led us to this moment and what might lead us out, measures of public sentiment back Stucke's reading of the room.

A 2018 report by the Pew Research Center found the real average wage -- accounting for inflation -- to be on par with the purchasing power of the real average wage from 1978. About 63 percent of respondents to a different Pew survey that same year said they felt the U.S. economic system unfairly advantages the rich.

While oil, steel and railroads fueled the fortunes of the original robber barons, the modern U.S. economy runs on code, and the tech titans of Silicon Valley are the face of modern wealth. They are also the target of our other, more faceless concerns about privacy, surveillance, autonomy and even the future of democratic governance itself.

Facebook is not just a social network, but one of the world's largest advertising platforms -- and available globally. Nearly three years after the 2016 elections, the degree to which Russia sought to sway the outcome by using digital tools -- not only Facebook but also Google and Twitter -- to reach U.S. voters is still being realized.

Other elections globally, such as the United Kingdom's 2016 Brexit vote or recent EU elections, are also subject to interference from malicious actors using digital platforms. Facebook now frequently publishes updates about banning "inauthentic" actors from its site, such as a May 6 release involving two separate operations originating in Russia that created "networks of accounts to mislead others about who they were and what they were doing."

Against this backdrop of both economic frustration and political frustration, the building tide of backlash becomes easier to see.

Political Winds

Though the formal congressional investigation has only just begun, Washington sentiment has been slowly turning against Big Tech.

Last September the Justice Department, at the time under the leadership of former Attorney General Jeff Sessions, held a meeting with attorneys general from eight states and the District of Columbia to discuss ways in which privacy issues from Facebook and other tech firms might be challenged as anticompetitive.

President Donald Trump in November also offhandedly said during a televised interview that "we are certainly looking at" potential antitrust violations on the part of Facebook, Amazon and Google.

The DOJ has taken initial steps toward the opening of a federal antitrust investigation into Alphabet's Google, The Washington Post reported in May. The company escaped significant punishment over its alleged anticompetitive practices in 2012 when the FTC found no violation of antitrust law from the way Google arranges search engine results, but its luck may be running out.

Democrats, too, are considering the question as one of many issues on the crowded 2020 campaign field.

Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren has for several years championed strong antitrust action to increase competition in the market, boost the creation of new business and both reduce prices and increase wages for consumers and workers. In March, she announced a public pledge to use antitrust law to break up existing large tech firms as a plank of her presidential campaign.

The 2020 presidential race is very much the biggest open question casting a shadow over any and all investigations of potentially anticompetitive behavior in the tech sector. Who will sit in the White House, and what they believe, can change everything.

Recent history provides an example: The DOJ mounted an antitrust case against Microsoft in the late 1990s, alleging the company was not only behaving anticompetitively in the way it bundled other products such as Internet Explorer in with its Windows operating system, but in doing so was also violating a 1994 settlement agreement.

In the spring of 2000, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia issued a judgment split into two parts. The first determined Microsoft's dominant position in the personal computer market to be a monopoly and found that the company had acted anticompetitively to quash potential threats.

The second followed the DOJ's request and ordered Microsoft broken up as a remedy. The order indicated the company should become two distinct entities: One to produce the Windows operating system, and the other to produce Microsoft's other software, including Internet Explorer and the Office suite of products.

The D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals in 2001 vacated Jackson's ruling, and in September 2001 the DOJ -- now under the administration of Republican President George W. Bush -- said it was no longer seeking to break up the company, instead pursuing different penalties.

Taking a breakup off the table "was a political decision," Stucke says. "It wasn't necessarily a legal consequence. If [Democrat Al] Gore was elected, there might have been a different Microsoft. We just don't know. It's not like there are just these natural forces in play."

Meantime, tech companies are working hard to woo lawmakers to their side.

Google spent about $21.7 million on lobbying in 2018, the eighth-highest amount of any single organization or company, according to data published by the nonpartisan Center for Responsive Politics. Amazon and Facebook also cracked the top 20 last year, spending $14.4 million and $12.6 million, respectively.

European Crackdown

U.S. regulators in fact are among the last in an information-economy world to take on the technology firms in Washington's own backyard.

Germany's competition regulator, the Bundeskartellamt, launched an investigation into potentially anticompetitive behavior by Amazon last November, "supplementing" another probe into Amazon's treatment of third-party merchants being run by the European Commission's competition bureau.

The Bundeskartellamt also imposed "far-reaching restrictions" on Facebook in February, limiting its ability to collect and collate user data from multiple sources without explicit consent, citing "exploitative abuse" of users.

"Facebook will no longer be allowed to force its users to agree to the practically unrestricted collection and assigning of non-Facebook data to their Facebook user accounts," Bundeskartellamt President Andreas Mundt said in a February statement.

Many authorities, advocates and activists have questioned Facebook's methods for gathering and using consumer data, but the ruling from the Bundeskartellamt is the first to challenge its data practices directly on the grounds of market dominance.

In light of Facebook's unmatched market power, the Bundeskartellamt determined, "an obligatory tick on the box to agree to the company's terms of use is not an adequate basis for such intensive data processing," because the user's choice "cannot be referred to as voluntary consent."

European Union regulators have also been busy. The EU in March fined Google 1.49 billion euros for antitrust violations, the third time in as many years the commission penalized Google for anticompetitive conduct. The first, in June 2017, was a then-record 2.42 billion euro fine; a year later, in July 2018, the commission again set a new record by hitting Google with a 4.3 billion euro fine for abusing market power with regards to bundled software, such as the Chrome browser and Google search tools, on Android phones.

Commissioner Margrethe Vestager, antitrust chief for the European Commission, in a May interview also said she was "definitely not done yet" with investigating and potentially penalizing U.S. tech firms.

Competition regulators in Australia, the United Kingdom, Canada and other jurisdictions have likewise been considering how best to regulate tech firms and are discussing where the line between massive market power and anticompetitive market dominance is best drawn.

Public Pressure

Some investors, tired of waiting for Washington to act, are taking matters into their own hands. A resolution put forward for consideration at Alphabet's annual meeting of shareholders suggested that Alphabet "may be too large and complex to be managed effectively," and noted that both U.S. and EU officials "continue to be concerned about Alphabet's market power in view of restrictions on monopolies."

In light of those concerns, the resolution said, the board should study "strategic alternatives" for the business, including pre-emptively selling off some businesses or assets, as doing so would be more likely to maximize shareholder value than a breakup by regulators.

Alphabet investors, following the recommendation of the board, voted against the resolution at the company's June 19 meeting. Facebook faced a very similar shareholder resolution at its annual meeting in May, which was also voted down.

Who Is Harmed?

Ultimately any effort to rein in the tech behemoths may require wrestling with the key antitrust question: Can the government show that anyone is hurt by the alleged anticompetitive behavior?

Traditionally, regulators have focused on monopoly pricing power -- whether a company or group of participants is so dominant in a market that it can raise prices at will. With Google, Facebook and others providing their consumer products for free, a broader approach to judging harm may be needed, regulators say.

Existing law is up to the challenge, Makan Delrahim, the assistant attorney general in charge of the Antitrust Division at DOJ, said when he addressed the issue at a conference in Tel Aviv on June 11. But he added that the definition of harm from anticompetitive behaviors may be due for some careful reconsideration.

"Price effects alone do not provide a complete picture of market dynamics, especially in digital markets in which the profit-maximizing price is zero," he said.

Indeed, the financial cost for the end consumer to use a service such as Facebook or Google is $0, which makes it difficult to argue that the companies' behavior is harmful based on price. Consumers typically don't pay for those services, which generate profit by monetizing users' app and web histories and data they often unknowingly provide.

That tradeoff of privacy for access, however, can involve another kind of payment -- and as German regulators recently determined, consumers making that trade may not be fully willing or fully informed.

A lack of competition, due to an anticompetitive marketplace, can harm product quality, Delrahim said, and privacy and data protections can be considered under that "product quality" banner.

Multiple companies in a sector can "compete to expand privacy protections for products or services, or for greater openness and free speech on platforms," he told his audience in Tel Aviv.

"Where competition is harmed, consumers and markets lose with higher prices, lower quality, lower rate of innovation, less free speech and even lower privacy protections," Delrahim concluded. "Protecting competition means protecting all of those dimensions of competition."

urn:contentItem:6055-HH51-JCMN-Y42X-00000-00Pressure mounts on Tim Cook to testify to Congress as other tech CEOs agree2020-06-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:52ZLexisNexisPressure mounts on Tim Cook to testify to Congress as other tech CEOs agreeBen Lovejoy

Jun 17, 2020( 9to5Mac: http://9to5mac.com Delivered by Newstex) Pressure is mounting on Apple[1] CEO Tim Cook[2] to testify to Congress on antitrust[3] concerns as other tech giants indicate they will send their chief execs to give evidence. Amazon[4], Facebook[5] and Google[6] are all reported to be willing to have their CEOs face questions about whether their companies are engaging in anti-competitive behaviors The Washington Post[7] says the three companies have 'signalled' their plans, while Apple has not. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and Google CEO Sundar Pichai signaled they are open to testifying to Congress as part of lawmakers' ongoing antitrust probe into the tech industry, while Apple has not yet explicitly agreed to send its leader.

The companies' commitments came in letters sent this weekend to the House Judiciary Committee, which has been investigating big tech since last year, according to two people familiar with the matter [] Amazon chief executive Jeff Bezos also has signaled he will participate in the hearing, after the e-commerce giant initially resisted lawmakers' demands [] Apple, meanwhile, told the committee that it would send a senior executive yet did not clearly commit its leader. The bipartisan Congressional probe is aiming to find out whether tech giants capitalize on their size to give themselves an unfair advantage over smaller companies, and whether they act in ways which are contrary to the best interests of consumers. In Apple's case, most of the concerns center on the cut the company takes from App Store sales and in-app payments and subscriptions. We've noted before[8] that this is just one of a slew of antitrust investigations into Apple. Apple is facing antitrust investigations on a number of fronts. In addition to the Congressional hearings, theDepartment of Justice[9]has its own investigation; theFederal Trade Commission[10]is investigating the legality of a deal between Apple and Amazon;a number of US states[11]are carrying out wide-ranging antitrust inquiries of their own;there are[12]anumber[13]ofcases[14]inother[15]countries; anda slew of lawsuits[16]. The latest of these was announced just yesterday[17]. Apple is now formally facing investigations on its conduct regarding the App Store and Apple Pay. European competition commissioner Margrethe Vestager today said that the probes are a priority and revolve around Apple's role as gatekeeper. The Apple Pay investigation will look into whether Apple unfairly locked out competing contactless payment services by restricting the use of the NFC chip inside iPhones. The App Store investigation centers on the mandatory use of Apple In-App Purchase system for third-party apps, and the 30% revenue cut that implies. AsDaring Fireball[18] suggests, agreement from the other companies makes it seen unavoidable for Tim Cook to testify in person at the hearings. 'I'll go if you go' sounds a lot like the social dance of teenagers, but, well, some social interactions scale all the way up to the CEOs of the biggest companies in the world. If Bezos, Pichai, and Zuckerberg all testify, trust me, Cook will be there. FTC: We use income earning auto affiliate links. More.[19] Check out 9to5Mac on YouTube for more Apple news:[20] [embedded content] [ 1]: https://9to5mac.com/guides/aapl/ [ 2]:   https://9to5mac.com/guides/tim-cook/ [ 3]:   https://9to5mac.com/guides/antitrust/ [ 4]:   https://amzn.to/2zG1trh [ 5]:   https://9to5mac.com/guides/facebook/ [ 6]:   https://9to5mac.com/guides/google/ [ 7]:   https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2020/06/16/apple-facebook-google-antitrust/ [ 8]:   https://9to5mac.com/2020/01/17/testify-against-apple/ [ 9]:   https://9to5mac.com/2019/10/24/tech-giant-antitrust-investigation/ [ 10]:   https://9to5mac.com/2019/08/02/apple-amazon/ [ 11]:   https://9to5mac.com/2019/07/26/antitrust-investigations/ [ 12]:   https://9to5mac.com/2015/05/07/apple-beats-music-spotify-complaint/ [ 13]:   https://9to5mac.com/2018/07/11/apple-antitrust-japan-2/ [ 14]:   https://9to5mac.com/2019/07/04/south-koreas-antitrust-regulator/ [ 15]:   https://9to5mac.com/2019/08/08/another-antitrust-investigation/ [ 16]:   https://9to5mac.com/2019/06/17/avoid-tech-stocks/ [ 17]:   https://9to5mac.com/2020/06/16/eu-apple-pay-iap-probes/ [ 18]:   https://daringfireball.net/ [ 19]:   https://9to5mac.com/about/#affiliate [ 20]:   https://www.youtube.com/c/9to5mac?sub_confirmation=1

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VR5-TYM1-F12B-J45V-00000-00Pressure on social media mounting2019-03-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:52ZLexisNexisGENERAL NEWSPg. A004Pressure on social media mounting

Countries already grappling with toxic behaviour online have redoubled efforts

Pressure is mounting on the world?(EURO)(TM)s social media giants following the Christchurch mosque shootings.

Countries already grappling with how to rein in the behaviour of platforms such as Facebook and Twitter and force them to act responsibly have redoubled their efforts, New Zealand among them.

There is also widespread agreement that nations must act together to force a change in how social media deals with harmful digital content.

Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, senior ministers and the Privacy Commissioner have all been highly critical of social media firms, especially Facebook, after the March 15 shootings, which were livestreamed.

Sharing the video has effectively been banned by Chief Censor David Shanks and doing so incurs a fine of up to $10,000 or up to 14 years?(EURO)(TM) jail.

Privacy Commissioner John Edwards has also called on Facebook to give the names of people who distributed the video to police.

Ardern has criticised the response by Facebook and other social media companies, saying there were still questions to be answered over their actions after the massacre.

Cabinet is expected to discuss if social media platforms can be forced to comply, but there is widespread acknowledgement that a cross-border approach is needed.

Andrew Little, the Minister Responsible for the SIS and GCSB, has said the use of social media to spread hate speech and incite violence would likely be discussed by the Five Eyes intelligence-sharing network when it meets in Britain this year.

In Australia, Prime Minister Scott Morrison and Opposition Leader Bill Shorten are due to meet social media executives today to discuss violent offences being broadcast by perpetrators on sites such as Facebook and YouTube following the mosque shootings, SBS reported.

?(EURO)oeIt?(EURO)(TM)s no good for the people who run the swamp ... to then not take responsibility for what crawls out,?(EURO) Shorten told reporters yesterday.

Under sweeping changes proposed for Australia?(EURO)(TM)s Privacy Act, online platforms that seriously or repeatedly breached privacy laws would be fined A$10 million ($10.2m) compared with the current penalty of A$2.1m, according to SBS.

Morrison has also called for a crackdown by G20 nations on social media giants and has reportedly asked for it to be a top agenda item when the G20 meets next in Japan.

Attorney-General David Parker raised social media liability at a meeting with his Five Eyes counterparts ?(EURO)" the United States, Britain, Canada and Australia ?(EURO)" last August. He declined to talk about it yesterday.

Speaking at the recent swearing in of Justice Helen Winkelmann as Chief Justice before the mosque shootings, Parker predicted challenges for her in the area of social media. ?(EURO)oeWhere does the limit lie between freedom of speech and harmful fake news or hateful propaganda??(EURO) he asked.

?(EURO)oeWhat duties are owed by those who profit from social media platforms to society, private citizens, or to the public institutions which democracy relies upon?

?(EURO)oeThese are very important and complex issues for our time and the wisdom of the courts you lead will help achieve wise outcomes.?(EURO)

And speaking after an assault on Green Party co-leader James Shaw just a day before the mosque shootings, Parker criticised the role of social media in spreading extreme opinions that fed political biases.

He said the British digital culture, media and sport select committee, which looked into the issues of disinformation and fakes news, was right to call out the kind of extreme opinion shared via social media which fuelled biases and caused instability among some people.

?(EURO)oeWe need to reflect upon what?(EURO)(TM)s going on in society that causes people to be so extreme in their reactions to things they disagree with,?(EURO) he said of last month?(EURO)(TM)s report.

The committee called for:

?-A compulsory code of ethics for tech companies overseen by an independent regulator.

?-The regulator to be funded by a levy on tech companies operating in Britain.

?-Powers for the regulator to launch legal action against companies breaching the code of ethics.

?-Social media companies obliged to take down known sources of harmful content, including proven sources of disinformation.

?-Hefty fines for companies that fail in their obligations on harmful or illegal content.

In releasing the report, MP Damian Collins said: ?(EURO)oeDemocracy is at risk from the malicious and relentless targeting of citizens with disinformation and personalised ?(EURO)~dark adverts?(EURO)(TM) from unidentifiable sources, delivered through the major social media platforms we use every day.?(EURO)

Collins said the big tech companies were failing in the duty of care they owed to their users to act against harmful content.

?(EURO)oeThese are issues that the major tech companies are well aware of, yet continually fail to address. The guiding principle of the ?(EURO)~move fast and break things?(EURO)(TM) culture often seems to be that it is better to apologise than ask permission.?(EURO)

Little, who is also in charge of the Harmful Digital Communications Act, says there is a willingness in Government to look more closely at what is wrong with social media and what powers could be used to rein in the worst aspects of it.

He agreed social media was becoming more toxic. ?(EURO)oeIt?(EURO)(TM)s kind of got to the point where it?(EURO)(TM)s almost a parody of itself. You go on Twitter to bathe in the toxicity and putrescence of it.

?(EURO)oeOn the other hand, I?(EURO)(TM)ve seen stuff on Facebook which causes my toes to curl and wonder about the mentality of some people.?(EURO)

The act was about ?(EURO)oeclear expressions of hatred and threats expressed towards individuals through the internet, social media platforms and the like?(EURO), Little said.

?(EURO)oeOne of the challenges [for] the law always has been to draw that line between upholding and protecting free speech but on the other hand clearly dealing with expressions that are calculated to cause harm or incite others to cause harm.

?(EURO)oeThe law is always trying to find that balance. I believe that legislation that we?(EURO)(TM)ve got in place ... does that.

?(EURO)oeIf there?(EURO)(TM)s any call for review or change, let?(EURO)(TM)s have a look at that.?(EURO)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TH3-75V1-DXKP-J1XP-00000-00Preventing the 'Big Hack';Big tech needs to prioritize security over its bottom line.2018-10-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:52ZLexisNexisPreventing the 'Big Hack'Big tech needs to prioritize security over its bottom line.Lillian Ablon

Lillian Ablon is an information scientist at the RAND Corporation.

There's no better way to kick off cybersecurity awareness month than with an explosive story involving a foreign country successfully infiltrating the supply chain of U.S. companies and surreptitiously implanting malicious computer chips into components so widely used that the aftermath could ricochet around the world.

Whether the attack even happened is subject to debate. Bloomberg broke the news of China's alleged attack earlier this month, but many experts, U.S. and U.K. security agencies and the Silicon Valley-based companies whose products were supposedly affected, all expressed strong doubt that the attack happened in the manner reported, if at all. I count myself among them.

True or not, the report fueled an important discussion about whether businesses should make security more of a priority when it comes to their supply chains. Even the simplest devices can rely on parts from multiple suppliers, which may have their own suppliers and so on. But every supplier, no matter how small, represents a potential weak link in the chain. Hardware or software can present an entry for attack. Parts and algorithms can be altered to introduce malicious behavior. The technology used to manage the supply chain that provides the parts - such as the databases that hold contracting or ordering information - can also be breached and manipulated.

Supply chain risk management, as it's known, is the process of identifying vulnerabilities and threats to a supply chain and developing strategies to prevent a disruption anywhere along the road, from design to production to distribution. It encompasses cyber as well as more conventional threats. And yet, while every supplier in the chain needs to consider ensuring their systems are protected from tampering, identifying each supplier is a herculean task. It's impossible to determine which ones pose the most risk if you can't identify them, let alone try to ensure they comply with the most effective security practices. When the supplier is a continent away, the task is even more difficult.

Furthermore, the suppliers are running a business and want to maintain a competitive advantage. Companies are reticent to identify their sub-suppliers since a customer might skip the intermediary to obtain parts for less. Or a supplier lower on the chain might try to negotiate a higher price after learning what fancy product is being manufactured.

Solutions - largely commercially available products and frameworks - do exist to help manage supply-chain risks posed by conventional threats, including disruptions in operations caused by natural disasters, financial failures or poor-quality products. They offer features like geographic visualization that give locations and transportation routes of critical assets in the supply chain, real-time monitoring that provides news and updates about suppliers and compliance trackers to keep track of industry regulations.

But none of these solutions magically provides full visibility into a product's supply chain and processes, and most do not explicitly address vulnerabilities and threats specific to cybersecurity. This is likely because the cyber component of supply chain risk management is so nascent, and it is already a challenge to address conventional risks.

Furthermore, the unwillingness or inability of suppliers to share specific details about their supply chains could hamper the effectiveness of such solutions. While some sub-tier suppliers, in particular those supplying the Department of Defense, are required to report their security posture back to the top-level company or agency purchasing the product, there is often no oversight or auditing to make them prove they are maintaining appropriate security standards. Having formal requirements for doing so could help in selecting "less risky" suppliers and might reduce the overall likelihood of malicious manipulation.

One way to create such oversight is for the government to create a new authority that focuses on supply chain security and has the power to conduct meaningful audits. Or the task could be shared by existing organizations that already assess conventional supply chain risk.

Even if the the "Big Hack," as Bloomberg called it, never happened, it serves as a potent reminder of the cybersecurity risks to the supply chain. Companies also need to do their part by establishing internal teams to oversee and guide risk assessments and audits of suppliers, lengthen timelines for production to make it easier to monitor the supply chain, and purchase goods from suppliers that comply with basic cybersecurity standards and are verified by an independent third-party organization.

Functionality, timeliness and profitability are often at odds with security - until a cyberattack occurs. When an actual attack on the supply chain occurs, manufacturers and purchasers should be better positioned to respond and recover. Even in this modern high-tech era, old-fashioned oversight could make all the difference.

This was produced by The WorldPost , a partnership of the Berggruen Institute and The Washington Post.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60DK-G4S1-JBYT-H1DP-00000-00Price of entry or corporate strategy: how pharma and biotech are approaching digital health2020-07-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:52ZLexisNexisPrice of entry or corporate strategy: how pharma and biotech are approaching digital healthNew Delhi, 2020-07-22 13:16:11

July 22 -- The high costs of drug discovery and commercialization, looming patent cliffs, and increasing regulatory pressure on drug pricing have created a perfect storm of margin and growth pressures on the pharma sector. In an apparent response to these pressures, M&A activity in pharma is back. This month, Bristol-Myers Squibb announced its $74 Billion acquisition of Celgene, and Eli Lilly did the same with its $8 Billion acquisition of Loxo. (At the recently concluded JP Morgan Healthcare Conference (JPM), the pharma/biotech sector's biggest event of the year, Eli Lilly's CEO indicated that conditions are ripe for an M & A uptick in 2019)


Acquisitions may be one way to stay on top of the marketplace changes; however, organic growth pressures remain. One way to address the challenge is through digital transformation. However, digital strategies within and across individual sub-sectors in healthcare may look different depending on what companies want to achieve at a corporate level, at a commercial level, and a technology level.
Digital in pharma: eliminating frictionHealthcare is on a mission to put the focus back on patients, improve engagement levels and achieve better healthcare outcomes, and reduce costs. Digital has become the price of entry into a future state implied by this renewed focus. Digital is also seen as a powerful tool for differentiation.
The most crucial purpose of a digital strategy may be the elimination of friction in the healthcare value chain. There are many areas that are ripe for improvement in pharma. One of them is to enable drug development by being able to measure things objectively to prove drug efficacy and demonstrate value. Another is to accelerate clinical trials through improved ways of recruiting and managing patients. Yet another is to develop digital therapeutic solutions to augment revenue streams.
Greg Silvesti, Head of Digital Health and Innovation at Abbvie, (a $28.2 billion company best known for its blockbuster drug Humira), says that pharma companies are dancing on a pinhead for differentiation today. He suggests that digital itself isn't a strategy but an enabler to an overall strategy and a tool to unlock value. An overall digital strategy can be a combination of approaches depending on the strategic goals of the company. However, the key is building the approach with digital as an enabling technology for the overall strategy of the company.
The maturing of digital health and its challenges in pharmaThe digital health space has matured in the last few years, attracting an eye-popping $8.1 billion in venture capital funding in 2018. There is no question that we are seeing a shift in how healthcare is being delivered through new digital health solutions. Telehealth is growing, as is remote monitoring. Vast amounts of increasingly diverse data sources from sensors and devices can now be aggregated and combined with traditional data sources such as electronic health records. Advanced analytical tools are now available to process these vast amounts of data in low-cost infrastructure on the cloud to develop and deliver insights at the point of care.
However, the digital health startup ecosystem has not made as much progress as expected. Many startups have failed, and many are unable to provide an exit to investors. Even big tech firms with huge investments in health cloud platforms are yet to make a significant impact. I have discussed some of the challenges for digital health startups in general including the Last Mile problem and the Law of Small Numbers in earlier columns here.
Succeeding in pharma requires digital health companies to recognize some unique principles and characteristics of the sector.
 
A positive ecosystem supports growth of all participants. Huawei Cloud aims to establish an ecosystem to help partners across the globe.
Data is not worth muchA few years back, everybody was fascinated by just the data that could come off of a smart sensor or wearable. The internet of things (IoT) was all the rage. What we have seen since is that there is not that much value in data; in addition to issues with data quality, sufficiency, and interoperability, simply being able to capture transactional metrics off of smart sensors and wearables does not create tremendous value, unless we are able to obtain actionable information by using advanced analytics such as artificial intelligence or AI.  
Forget the widget, focus on the problemFor many startups, digital health comes down to just an app. Startups that develop interesting technology also get stuck in trying to figure out a healthcare problem to apply it to; essentially, actually attacking the issue backwards. Silvesti advises people to get out of the mindset of being too enamored by the "widget." He urges companies to focus more around the problems that pharma is trying to solve, for example in a patient population, and then working backwards into the ultimate solution for that patient population.  
Recognize that pharma and the tech sector operate at different speedsPharma does not speak the same language as the tech sector and operates in a very traditional and straightforward way which may seem agonizingly slow to most of the tech sector (just ask startups that pivoted from a B2C to a B2B model thinking it will yield quicker results for their investors). Pharma is also much more deliberate in thinking about buy-borrow-build options for technology solutions. For their part, digital health companies have to resist building out a product completely; instead build it up to about 50% to 60% of the way, leaving room to develop the rest with a partner. Many pharma companies, including Abbvie, have set up innovation funds that take stakes in promising startups and actively collaborate on developing the products. (At the JPM conference, GlaxoSmithKline's CEO indicated the company would also be buying some of these early stage assets.)
Ultimately, digital in pharma is not about the technologies; it is about solving the right problem and allowing the solution to evolve. It is taking a step back right from the sexiness of the technology which we all love to talk about and ensuring that everything is truly grounded in corporate strategy. In that sense, digital in and of itself it is not a strategy but an enabler to the broader bigger strategy.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VBD-YJV1-F021-614V-00000-00Priests cannot be judgmental when giving communion2019-02-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:53ZLexisNexisNEWSVersion:1Priests cannot be judgmental when giving communionThe Sunday Times

I was filled with surprise and anger when I read your story "

Pro-choice TD Troy is denied holy communion

" (News, last week). Not being a practising Catholic, the idea of being refused communion wouldn't bother me in the slightest. However, for a priest to set himself up as judge, jury and executioner to decide who should receive the body of Christ is beyond belief.

The Christ I see when I pray at night is a loving, caring and non-judgmental being. Not some craw thumper who thinks he is God's emissary down here.

Pat Burke Walsh, Gorey, Co Wexford Divine intervention

Pro-life people of all religions, and none, were saddened and demoralised by the Irish electorate's decision to delete the eight amendment from our constitution. From a Catholic perspective it was particularly appalling that "Catholic" politicians seemed to do so with impunity.

A number of brave priests did step up to the mark and clearly state that support for abortion was incompatible with Catholicism. In this context it is heartening to learn that Fr John Hogan refused communion to a politician who effectively voted for abortion. Congratulations to him.

Can all of his colleagues in the Catholic church, and other churches, please copy.

Eric Conway, Navan, Co Meath Insult to injury

Of course if you have "only" abused children or turned a blind eye to abuse, communion won't be withheld. The principles of the Catholic church become clearer by the day.

Rob Zenker, Switzerland Fighting back

I support Fr John Hogan in his action of withholding the host from anyone who voted to terminate the lives of the unborn. It is time for the Catholic church to fight back against our shameful decision.

Teresa Mitchell, Arklow, Co Wicklow Holier than thou

After spending all of my life working in England, I returned to Ireland on the basis that the priest-ridden country I had left behind no longer existed.

How wrong I was, as I can now see after a priest in Westmeath refused to give communion to a Fianna Fail TD at a recent requiem mass because he had supported the introduction of legalised abortion services. It begs the question as to how many priests of this ilk are still out there.

To paraphrase a well-known remark, they haven't gone away, you know.

Peter Pallas, Bantry, Co Cork Cross words

This is only newsworthy because Ireland has yet to fully sever itself from the Catholic church. The state should be separate from, and neutral towards, all forms of spirituality. Once that is accomplished, it would be unremarkable that Catholic politicians who supported gay marriage, abortion etc could not remain "in good standing" with the church.

The private spirituality of Irish politicians would then be just that - private. Today, alas, the Irish state and Catholicism are intertwined, yielding poor results for both.

Charles Klingman, Berlin Praying to the crowd

Robert Troy is an exemplary young man, and what happened to him was embarrassing and hurtful. I'm sure the priest concerned would have acted differently if he had known it would draw such media attention.

Terry Mooney, by email PROTECT VICTIMS OF THE SEX TRADE

Brenda Power's comments about prostitution ("

Old johns aren't the issue, so legalise prostitution to stop the traffickers

", Comment, last week) included misconceptions that are important to address.

Calls to legalise the sex trade are often well intentioned. However, it is paradoxical to assert that "pimps and traffickers should be the target of our legislation" while also endorsing "legalisation".

Legalising prostitution includes decriminalising pimping, and doesn't result in a reduction in sex trafficking. This is evident from regimes such as those in Germany and the Netherlands where pimps and traffickers benefit from these laws.

Normalising prostitution through legalisation increases demand. With growing demand come increasing vacancies to fill by coaxing, tricking and abusing vulnerable and impoverished women, including promises of a better life which don't materialise behind the closed doors of a brothel.

Sex buyers are not a benign cohort. Our 2018 campaign Andreea, available on the Ruhama YouTube channel, featured a fictitious prostituted woman identifying herself as a victim of trafficking. Some 68% of prospective buyers who called her nonetheless requested sexual services.

We advocate that those selling or sold for sex are legally protected. A vital component of the recent Sexual Offences Act 2017 was the decriminalisation of individuals in prostitution. The only law striving to meaningfully reduce the exploitation of prostitution is this "partial decriminalisation" model: decriminalising the seller while targeting both criminal organisations and demand.

Amanda Keane, Ruhama Caught in the act

Proponents of the 2017 act argued that a fear of prosecution for buying sexual services would lead to a fall in the number of clients, leading to a fall in the number of prostitutes required to cater for the reduced client base and, crucially, a consequent reduction in the number of girls trafficked as their transnational pimps noted the dramatic shrinkage in the number of Irish clients willing to risk conviction.

In other words, this law was introduced as a result of a crass conflation of trafficking and prostitution.

How many people have been convicted of trafficking for prostitution since the law was introduced? Apparently none.

The weight of outrage and determination for justice should have been specifically directed at those trafficking pimps - but in fact we already had specific legislation addressing that. The conflation of "ordinary", "domestic" prostitution with trafficking and transnational sex slavery was pointless. More importantly it was counterproductive, and is obviously proving unworkable.

C MacCarthy, by email Power ahead

I only buy one newspaper a week - The Sunday Times - and I congratulate you on the high standard of your writers. The one I most look forward to each week is Brenda Power. In the middle of screaming outrage, she is the voice of reason and common sense. It was recognised as a gift in the old days, and Power has it in abundance.

WM Patterson Manorcunningham, Co Donegal IRELAND IS VICTIM OF BREXIT FOLLY

Ireland did not vote for Brexit, Britain's folly, yet is going to be devastated by it, and some British people do not care one whit ("

Border? What Border?

", News Review, last week). Brexit, and its inevitable borders, are Britain's responsibility; it is they who voted for this mess. Yet Ireland is being victimised due to Britain's lack of planning, lack of interest, and arrogance.

Carrie McIntyre, Drogheda, Louth Heavyweight opportunity

Never in the field of political conflict has such a number of inept self-serving politicians been assembled in the mother of parliaments. As a result of the Brexit fiasco, people in Northern Ireland must surely now realise that the English do not care about this state, other than being kept in power by the Democratic Unionist Party.

That caricature of a politician Jacob Rees-Mogg once described the taoiseach Leo Varadkar as "a rather lightweight Irish gentleman". Well, his government have succeeded in making the taoiseach, a man bereft of any statesmanship, appear gargantuan. The UK's difficulty is now the Republic of Ireland's opportunity. And why not?

Wilson Burgess, Derry Undemocracy rules

Some 56% of the Northern Ireland electorate voted to remain. That rises to 65% in a recent opinion poll. All political parties in Northern Ireland, with the exception of the DUP, are remainers.

Those same parties, again with the exception of the DUP, supported Theresa May's deal. The small business community and the CBI in Northern Ireland supported the deal; the (mainly Protestant) Ulster Farmers' Union supported the deal.

When Ken Clarke recently described the DUP as sectarian and Protestant, he could easily have added self-serving and undemocratic.

Stephen McGarrigle, Co Tyrone Check off

When will Irish politicians realise the Republic is a small, insignificant part of Europe and dependent for most of its trade on the UK? A workable system for off-border checks was proposed early in the negotiations and rejected by Varadkar for internal political reasons.

William Berrow, Northampton Tread carefully

David Quinn neatly highlighted the way Irish politicians tiptoed around any reference to nationalism or "taking back control" during the recent ceremonies to mark the meeting of the first Dail (Comment, last week). No doubt they were scared of using any rhetoric that might link them to those obstreperous Brits and their drive to escape Brussels rule.

Our leaders apparently see no contradiction in honouring the revolutionary movement while ceding large amounts of our hard-won independence to EU institutions.

Martin Hand, Marino, Dublin Down tools

Compromise will win. Everyone knows the EU is using Ireland as a negotiation tool. If they allow the border issue to be reopened, there will be a very negative reaction not just from the Irish but many others in the EU about how they force nation states to do things against their wills.

Ian Skeet, Reading POINTS Safe space

It is deeply concerning that material which effectively promotes suicide and self-harm is so easily accessible online ("Big Tech firms pushing teens into 'suicide trap'", News, last week). We know one in eight school children has a mental health condition, and the crisis is getting worse.

It's clear internet companies are not doing enough to keep children safe. Self-regulation just hasn't worked in the face of self-harm forums, gaming addiction, cyber-bullying and online grooming. Governments must act: any delay to act could put another generation in danger.

Javed Khan, Chief executive, Barnardo's Where were the adults?

Niall Ferguson talks of "emocracy" being driven by social media (Comment, last week), but why were schoolboys from Covington taken to attend a socio-politically charged rally at all, much less in such a location as the Lincoln Memorial in Washington? What planning was done to reduce the risk of the schoolboys being exposed to adults campaigning on other issues there?

Was there any reiteration of school policy with regard to decorum, or any specific edict about the emotiveness of wearing Make America Great Again hats in such an environment? Where were the responsible adult chaperones?

Michele Savage, Terenure, Dublin 6W Blank canvas

I went along to support the young people in Theatre 57, who are the future of arts in Galway ("

Culture shock for Galway 2020

", News, last week). Galway is great for running festivals and promoting street events by the likes of Macnas, but is an absolute "dead zone" in terms of its lack of provision for art to be displayed or performed. There is no public art gallery, no school of music, and no large concert venue. Wexford and Castlebar do it better.

Derrick Hambleton, Kingston, Galway Bono's tiny taxes

The gargantuan ego of pint-sized pop singer Bono knows no bounds (Quotes of the Week, last week). He was in Davos with taoiseach Leo Varadkar extolling the virtues of capitalism. It's no wonder he loves it, since his band U2 have availed of just about every tax scheme available over the years.

Mark O'Higgins, Dublin Fragile lives

Your articles about Queen Anne, one of the subjects of the film The Favourite, and the tragedy of her miscarriages and the deaths of her children, reminds us of the fragility of life (Culture, last week).

Our existence is far more vulnerable to health issues than we seem to realise. While we are aware of major problems such as the black death and Aids, we have little recognition about less calamitous events and the personal tragedies arising.

On this small island we have 17 place names that are variations on tamhlacht - plague grave. Antoine Ó Reachtabhra, one of the great poets in the Irish language, was blinded by smallpox in childhood and folklore has it that the last sight he remembered was of his eight siblings laid out dead on the floor of his family's cabin, all having succumbed.

Pádraig Ua Briain, Baile an Chabháin Irreplaceable McIlvanney

Thank you for the tributes to the late Hugh McIlvanney (News Review and Sport, last week). His sports writing was a joy and I followed him for more than 50 years. It was his knowledge of boxing that was so very impressive to me.

Whenever there was a big fight, McIlvanney would be there, filing two dispatches: a preview on the Sunday before and a report the next week, usually the day after the contest. He called the fight in the first dispatch and his assessments were uncanny. If he got one wrong it must have been when I was on holiday. You could put your house on his prediction - and Hugh probably did. Irreplaceable.

Paul Collins, East Grinstead, West Sussex Pained expression

I was initially sympathetic reading Rob McGibbon's "How it feels to... be a secret gout sufferer" (Magazine, last week). This evaporated when, complaining about how non-sufferers make light of his affliction, he wrote: "It's not the achy stuff that makes old folk grumble." He himself was making light of arthritis, a bane for millions in every age bracket.

Martin James, Haslemere, Surrey BIRTHDAYS Laurence Kinlan

, stage and screen actor, 36

Jim Lockhart

, musician, 71

CORRECTION

The Tax List (Magazine, last week) stated that Starbucks paid £4.6m in UK taxes last year. In fact the total figure was £13.7m. We apologise for the error.

value.Title: Primadonna mit Bauchgefühl

Extracts.SummaryText: ... Big-Tech an. 2016 verdonnerte Vestager Apple zu einer Steuernachzahlung von 13 Milliarden Euro, die der US -Konzern im Mitgliedsland Irland zu wenig entrichtet hatte. Sie führte gleich drei Verfahren gegen Google : weil der Konzern Produkte seiner Tochterunternehmen bei Suchanfragen bevorzugte, weil Google über sein Handybetriebssystem Android seine Suchmaschine zum Standard machte und weil Google seine marktbeherrschende Stellung missbrauchte. Am Ende standen Milliardenstrafen. Seit Wochen ...

Und natürlich legt sie sich immer wieder mit <xhtml:span class="hit">Big-Tech</xhtml:span> an. 2016 verdonnerte Vestager Apple zu einer Steuernachzahlung von 13 Milliarden ...</xhtml:span>

urn:contentItem:5W5T-5YM1-JDTJ-X0M3-00000-00Primadonna mit Bauchgefühl2019-05-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:52ZLexisNexisTITELS. 20Primadonna mit BauchgefühlBook, SimonWettach, SilkeZastiral, Sascha

Margrethe Vestager ist der heimliche Star der Europapolitik. Die so selbst- wie machtbewusste Wettbewerbskommissarin hat sich öffentlichkeitswirksam mit der deutschen Autoindustrie und amerikanischen Digitalkonzernen angelegt und sich dabei viele Feinde gemacht. Nun greift sie nach der EU-Präsidentschaft.

Im ehemals größten deutschen Paketpostamt kommt erst Stimmung auf, als Margrethe Vestager das Kommando übernimmt. Seit einer halben Stunde sitzt die EU-Kommissarin für Wettbewerb bei der re:publica in Berlin-Kreuzberg auf der Bühne. Die große Konferenz rund ums Infotainment in der Digitalgesellschaft ist für Vestager die perfekte Gelegenheit, um ein paar Grundsätzlichkeiten über Fairness und Wettbewerb in der Facebook- und Google-Welt loszuwerden.

Der Moderator hat die Dänin im Stil eines Marktschreiers als "Popstar der EU-Kommission" und eine der "gefürchtetsten Frauen im Silicon Valley" angekündigt. Doch was folgt, ist eine behäbige Fragerunde. Das Interesse des Publikums am Gast aus Brüssel ist begrenzt, viele scrollen auf Smartphones durch ihre Mails und Twitter-Accounts. Bis es Vestager reicht. Sie weiß, was ihre Fans im Auditorium hören wollen, sagt: "Ich glaube, viele hier teilen meine Frustration mit der Datenschutz-Grundverordnung: Es ist gut, dass wir diese digitalen Bürgerrechte jetzt haben. Aber es wäre noch schöner, wenn wir sie auch ausprobieren könnten." Endlich horcht der Saal auf. Vestager legt nach: "Das hätte jetzt aber einen viel, viel größeren Applaus geben müssen." Gelächter, gelöste Mienen, großer Applaus. Na also.

HANDELN UND WANDELN .

Vestager ist es gewohnt, dass sie das Tempo und die Richtung bestimmt. Sie hat die Milliardenfusion von O2 und Hutchison abgelehnt und den Zusammenschluss der Börsen in Frankfurt und London verhindert. Sie hat ein Lkw-Kartell zerschlagen und die in Berlin und Paris erwünschte Zusammenlegung der Bahnsparten von Siemens und Alstom abgeblasen. Derzeit prüft sie, ob deutsche Autobauer illegale Absprachen trafen, um die Einführung umweltfreundlicher Technologie zu verzögern. Und natürlich legt sie sich immer wieder mit Big-Tech an.

2016 verdonnerte Vestager Apple zu einer Steuernachzahlung von 13 Milliarden Euro, die der US-Konzern im Mitgliedsland Irland zu wenig entrichtet hatte. Sie führte gleich drei Verfahren gegen Google: weil der Konzern Produkte seiner Tochterunternehmen bei Suchanfragen bevorzugte, weil Google über sein Handybetriebssystem Android seine Suchmaschine zum Standard machte und weil Google seine marktbeherrschende Stellung missbrauchte. Am Ende standen Milliardenstrafen.

Seit Wochen denkt Vestager laut über eine Zerschlagung von Facebook nach, wenn auch als "last resort" der EU-Kartellpolitik. Und sie untersucht, ob Amazon die Daten von kleinen Verkäufern auf seiner Handelsplattform missbraucht, um sich ihnen gegenüber einen unrechtmäßigen Vorteil zu verschaffen. Man müsse darüber nachdenken, sagt Vestager, ob diese Daten wirklich Amazon gehörten - oder ob es dafür nicht eine quasistaatliche, unabhängige Daten-Verwaltungs-Agentur bräuchte.

Vestagers Handeln, ihre Auftritte, beeindrucken viele. Von der Netzelite wird sie gefeiert, von Konzernchefs gefürchtet, von Politikern bewundert, von Journalisten gewürdigt, inzwischen auch in den USA. Für den "Atlantic" ist sie "the most important technocrat of the century", für das "Wall Street Journal" die "Regulatorin des Silicon Valley", für "Foreign Policy" eine der zehn einflussreichsten "globalen Denkerinnen" der vergangenen zehn Jahre. Selbst US-Präsident Donald Trump, dessen Europakenntnisse sich oft darauf beschränken, dass er Belgien für eine "wunderschöne Stadt" hält, huldigt Vestager fast ehrfürchtig als "tax lady".

Weltweit ist der Name Vestager in den vergangenen Monaten fast schon zu einem Synonym geworden für die Selbstbehauptung Europas - für eine EU, die sich als Hort einer regelbasierten Wirtschaft begreift, als ordnungspolitische Alternative zum vulgären Nationalkapitalismus in den USA und zum Kaderkapitalismus in China.

Liberale Regierungschefs, darunter Frankreichs Staatspräsident Emmanuel Macron, verhehlen nicht, dass sie sich die Dänin als Nachfolgerin von EU-Kommissionspräsident Jean-Claude Juncker wünschen. Auch Kanzlerin Angela Merkel schätzt ihre Sachkenntnis und Entschlossenheit.

Und doch ist Vestagers Krönung nicht sicher. Nicht nur wird immer wieder Kritik laut am Führungsstil der Kommissarin. Auch sind zuletzt eine Reihe ihrer so populären Entscheidungen von Gerichten wieder kassiert worden. Vor allem aber gestaltet sich das Personal-Puzzle nach der Wahl zusehends schwierig. Zu viele Posten sind neu zu besetzen, zu viele Proportionalitäten zu berücksichtigen: Wer leitet künftig die Europäische Zentralbank? Wer wird Hoher Außenbeauftragter? Eine Chance auf den Top-Job hat Vestager wohl nur, wenn sich Macron und Merkel auf sie verständigen - und das Europaparlament davon ablässt, nur Spitzenkandidaten als Kommissionschef zuzulassen. Vestager ist eben das nicht. Und ihre liberale Fraktion mit ziemlicher Sicherheit nicht stärkste Kraft im Parlament.

Es ist ein Dilemma: Alle sind sich einig, dass niemand in Europa der liberalen Dänin derzeit das Wasser reicht, wenn es um wertegeleitete Unabhängigkeit und Glaubwürdigkeit geht, um Sachinteresse und Tatkraft. Dennoch hat sie ihre Zukunft nicht mehr selbst in der Hand.

Wer Vestager trifft, erlebt eine zuvorkommende, höfliche Frau, die doch ihr Selbst- und Machtbewusstsein kaum verhehlen kann. Natürlich, argumentiert Vestager, gehe es im Kampf gegen die Übermacht der Valley-Konzerne nie nur um ein paar Milliarden Euro. Sondern darum, wer die "Regeln für das nächste Jahrhundert" setzt: Facebook und Google - oder sie, Margrethe Vestager, im Interesse von 500 Millionen Europäern.

Die Kommissarin agiert, anders als ihr Vorgänger Joaquin Almunia, mit einer Mischung aus politischer Feinfühligkeit und Unnachgiebigkeit: um Popularität bemüht, ohne populistisch zu sein. Sie ignoriert in ihren Reden Europas Radikale, weil sie sie in der Minderheit weiß, sie nicht durch Aufmerksamkeit aufwerten will. Stattdessen lobt sie Europa als den "besten Platz zum Leben", auch wenn verständlich sei, warum sich viele Menschen von der EU abwendeten: Brüssel sei oft zu kompliziert, gewiss, zu unübersichtlich. Brüssel habe ein "Ort der Lösungen, nicht des Streits" zu sein.

BAUCHGEFÜHL UND KOPFKRITIK .

Kopenhagen, ein regnerischer Freitag, zwei Wochen vor der Europawahl. Margrethe Vestager hat sich einen schwarz-neongelben Schutzanzug über ihr farbfroh-geblümtes Seidenkleid gezogen und im Yachthafen, gleich hinter der Meerjungfrau, ein Speedboat bestiegen. Es geht zum Europe Youth Summit, ein Politik-Festival, das auf der künstlichen Insel im Hafen der dänischen Hauptstadt 200 Jugendliche versammelt.

Merkel oder Macron wären wohl mit dem Helikopter eingeflogen. Doch das passt nicht zum Auftritt der 51-Jährigen. Sie will ein neues, kraftvolles, dynamisches Europa verkörpern, sich dabei buchstäblich Wind und Wetter stellen. Und so steht sie, kaum angekommen, den Regen noch im kurzen, grauen, markant geschnittenen Haar, schon auf dem Kai und gibt Interviews, ruft wenig später, den Jugendlichen im Saal zu: "Es war meine Generation, die nicht verstanden hat, was der Klimawandel bedeutet. Wir brauchen euch, um Europa den richtigen Weg zu weisen. Wir brauchen euch, um unsere gemeinsame Zukunft zu bauen." Frenetischer Applaus. Ovationen im Stehen. Vestager "rockt", sagt einer der Organisatoren.

Sie hat das: ein Gespür für Situationen und Stimmungen. Kann sich in junge Menschen ebenso hineinversetzen wie in Professoren. Als die Mutter dreier Kinder Anfang Februar einen Hörsaal an der Universität Cambridge betritt, liest sie den Raum wie eines ihrer Kommissionspapiere. Sie sucht den Blickkontakt zu den Zuhörern, saugt die Stimmung auf, sagt dann, noch bevor sie über die neuen Herausforderungen für das EU-Wettbewerbsrecht referiert: "Ich biete Ihnen heute einen Brexit-freien Moment an." Stoßartig, als hätte jemand gut gelüftet, weicht die Spannung aus dem Raum, macht Platz für eine lockere, offene Debatte.

Bauchgefühl ist ihr politischer Kompass, ihr Instinkt legendär. Als Vestager in Brüssel ankam, dachte sie darüber nach: Wie führe ich am besten die Generaldirektion Wettbewerb? Am Ende, sagt sie, sei ihr "nichts wirklich Gutes" eingefallen. "Also habe ich es gemacht wie immer." Auf die "skandinavische Art": Jeder kann in seiner Rolle zum Erfolg beitragen. Hierarchie ist nicht so wichtig. Die Tür steht offen.

Bei ihren Beamten kommt das gut an. Vestager schenkt ihnen schon mal persönlich Kaffee ein, hört gut zu, durchdringt die Themen, gibt ihren Leuten das Gefühl, wichtig zu sein. Doch sie kann auch anders. Lob verteilt sie gerne persönlich, Tadel indes lässt sie überbringen - oder wird ihn vor versammelter Mannschaft los. Wie beim deutschen Juristen Johannes Laitenberger, ihrem obersten Beamten, den sie vor der Truppe zurechtwies, weil er auf Fachtagungen zu explizit angedeutet hatte, in welche Richtung sich die Kommission in Sachen Wettbewerbsrecht bewegen könnte. Sie sei die Kommissarin, beschied Vestager ihm. Sie verbreite Neuigkeiten. Niemand sonst.

Den Job erledigen. Die Öffentlichkeit wissen lassen, dass man ihn erledigt. Gut, gewissenhaft, kraftvoll. Der Rest kommt von allein. Das ist Vestagers Machtgeheimnis.

Wenngleich es daran auch Kritik gibt. Als sie gleich nach der Amtsübernahme 2014 den ersten Google-Fall neu aufrollte und dekretierte, der US-Konzern habe Wettbewerber in seiner Shopping-Suchmaschine prominent zu listen, da gab es dafür viel Applaus. Laut Vestager hat sich seither einiges getan, kommen kleinere Google-Wettbewerber zum Zug. Kritiker aber monieren, dass Google sich nicht an die Auflagen halte, "Vestager will das Thema aussitzen" ,so Fairsearch, eine Anti-Google-Lobbygruppe.

Auch andere prominente Fälle haken. Das EU-Gericht, die Instanz unter dem Europäischen Gerichtshof, hob zuletzt eine Serie von Vestagers Entscheidungen wieder auf, kam etwa zu dem Schluss, dass Belgien mit seinen Steuerrabatten für multinationale Konzerne nicht das EU-Recht verletze, wie von Vestager festgestellt. Das Urteil bestätigt jene Juristen, die davon ausgehen, dass auch Vestagers 13-Milliarden-Steuer-Nachforderung an Apple nicht Bestand haben wird.

SUPERMACHT UND KONTROLLVERLUST .

Vestager ficht das nicht an. Ihre Dänen sind ohnehin stolz auf die machtbewusste Kommissarin. Margarethe die Dritte nennen sie Vestager hier, als wäre sie eine Nachfahrin der Königin. Schon als Vize-Premier schrieb man ihr mehr Einfluss zu als der damaligen Regierungschefin Helle Thorning-Schmidt. Diesen "Machtinstinkt" habe sie in Brüssel geschärft, sagt eine alte Weggefährtin. Auch viele Europäer wünschen sich eine furchtlosere EU mit einer resoluten Kommissionsspitze. Und es ist kein Geheimnis, dass Vestager sich die Juncker-Nachfolge zutrauen würde. Als Ökonomin verfügt sie auch theoretisch über das Rüstzeug, um Europa im Systemwettbewerb richtig zu verorten, gerade gegenüber China. Dort gebe es "noch viel Spielraum für Europa, hartnäckiger zu sein, etwa beim globalen Handel", sagt Vestager. Das sei wohl ein Job für die Kommissionsspitze. Ein Job für sie.

Ist Vestager am Ende die richtige Frau, zur richtigen Zeit - nur in der falschen Partei? Um wirklich etwas zu ändern, sagt Margrethe Vestager gerne, auch an die Adresse der Regierungschefs gerichtet, müsse man sich selbst überwinden. "Das ist das Mutigste, was ein Mensch tun kann."

Damit das geschieht, muss es jedoch glücklich laufen für sie: am Sonntag in Europa. Und bei den Wahlen in Dänemark Anfang Juni. Und auch wenn es derzeit nicht danach aussieht, als ob Vestagers liberale Partei der nächsten Koalition in Kopenhagen angehören wird - vielleicht hilft ihr am Ende der Brüsseler Erfolg. "Ich bin in Kopenhagen beliebt, weil ich nicht hier bin", sagt sie.

In Europa ist es eher umgekehrt: Sie macht sich bei den Richtigen unbeliebt - und man freut sich, dass sie in Brüssel ist.
